newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: MICROSOFT, CHARGES SM SUMMIT WITH PIRACY.
newsitem.headline: MICROSOFT, CHARGES SM SUMMIT WITH PIRACY.

text.p: The Business Software Alliance (BSA) said on Wednesday it had raided the offices of SM Summit SUMM SI in Singapore after Microsoft and others had charged the firm with sofware piracy.

BSA officials told a news conference Microsoft, Adobe Systems Inc ADBE.O and Autodesk Inc had taken out a civil suit accusing SM Summit of software infringements, leading to the Tuesday night raid, which lasted 15 hours.
Market rumours of an argument between SM Summit and U.S. giant Microsoft sent the Singapore firm's stock plunging.
At 0155 GMT, Summit stock was trading at Singapore $0.755, down S$0.29.
Sheena Jacob, BSA's legal council in Singapore, told reporters the three firms had also taken out a suit against FAS Disc Manufacturing Private Ltd, another local company.
"We filed two civil suits yesterday," she said.
Lee Cross, BSA's regional legal council said:
"BSA has taken two enforcement actions against Summit Holdings and FAS. Both actions are connected to CD-ROM manufacture, illegal CD-ROM manufacture."
"Our mission is to stamp out piracy in the region and globally," she added.
Microsoft lawyer Ron Eckstrom said the raid began at noon (0400 GMT) on Tuesday and involved officers from BSA and a 26-strong team of police from Singapore's Criminal Investigation Department (CID).
They had "seized substantial documents from the premises of Summit Holdings", he said.
Officials at SM Summit were not immediately available for comment.
